title: 114_s1600
content: The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" allows citizens of designated countries to have privacy act remedies extended to them. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends civil remedies to covered persons for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Privacy Act, with exclusive remedies available under this section. Covered persons have the same rights and limitations as individuals in civil actions. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends civil remedies to covered persons for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Privacy Act. Covered persons have the same rights and limitations as individuals under section 552a of title 5, United States Code. The Attorney General, with the concurrence of other officials, may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has an agreement with the United States for privacy protections. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has an agreement with the United States for privacy protections and has effectively shared information for preventing criminal offenses. The designation can be revoked with the concurrence of other officials. The concurrence of the Secretary of State, Treasury, and Homeland Security can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if it fails to comply with the agreement, no longer meets requirements, or hinders information transfer to the US. The Attorney General determines designated Federal agencies for this purpose. The Attorney General designates Federal agencies for information exchange with covered countries based on agreements or designations of "covered countries" under specific criteria. The Attorney General designates agencies for information exchange with covered countries based on specific criteria, with determinations published in the Federal Register and not subject to review. The District of Columbia District Court has exclusive jurisdiction over claims arising under this section. The term "covered country" refers to a country or regional economic integration organization designated in accordance with specific criteria. A "covered person" is a natural person who is a citizen of a covered country. A "covered record" has the same meaning as a record under section 552a of title 5, once transferred to a designated Federal agency for criminal investigation purposes. The Act allows for the transfer of records to covered countries for criminal investigation purposes. A designated Federal agency or component can receive these records. The term "individual" is defined as per section 552a(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code. The Act does not waive privileges or require disclosure of classified information. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
